title: My Kid Started Soroban at 7 – Was That Too Late?
description: Everyone says 4-5 is the best age for Soroban. My child was already 7. I worried we missed the window.
imageAlt: Seven year old child learning with Soroban abacus

content.intro: "4-6 years old is the golden age for Soroban." I read that when my son was already 7. I felt a pang of regret: "Why didn't I know about this sooner?"

sections.text: At 4-6, kids' brains develop rapidly. They absorb everything like sponges. But that doesn't mean learning stops after 6.
Ages 7, 8, 9 – still great for learning Soroban. It might just take a bit more time compared to younger kids.
We Started at 7 – Here's What Happened
I was worried at first. But after 2 months, my son was doing great. He actually picked it up faster because he already knew numbers and basic addition.
Advantages of starting older: understands concepts quicker, can self-study, sits still longer.
There's no "too late" with Soroban. Kids at 10, even adults, can still learn. What matters is starting.
**Ages 4-6:** Learning for brain development and number familiarity. Keep expectations low.
**Ages 7-9:** Learning to support school math and build mental math. Clear, visible results.
**Ages 10+:** Still effective but requires more patience. Usually learning for specific goals like competitions or tutoring.
After 12 months with Sorokid, my son can mentally calculate 2-digit problems. His school math grades improved too.
I don't regret "finding out late" anymore. What matters is that we started.
Don't worry about being "too late." The best time to start is right now. Every day you don't start is another day delayed.

faq.question: Can a 10-year-old still learn Soroban?
faq.answer: Absolutely. Older kids actually understand concepts faster. They just need patience with the practice. Many 10-12 year olds do really well.

faq.question: What age is too young to start?
faq.answer: Under 4, most kids can't focus long enough. Ages 4-5 can start with play-based introduction to the abacus.

faq.question: Is there an age where it's truly too late?
faq.answer: Honestly, no. Even adults learn Soroban for brain training. The only difference is younger kids tend to reach competition levels more easily.
